description: Modern business corporations can be characterized as having their own internal cultures, more or less distinct from one another. They also exist within encompassing cultures and cultural flows. At the same time, corporations are producers and disseminators, and thus have effects on their surrounding environments, effects that extend from the local to the global. This course examines modern corporations from these three perspectives through theoretical and ethnographic readings, guest speakers from the corporate world, and independent research conducted by the students. Course requirements include student presentations of their research and readings; one or more take-home exams; and a final research paper.
name: ANTH OF CORPORATIONS

values.comments:
Modern business corporations can be characterized as having their own internal cultures, more or less distinct from one another. They also exist within encompassing cultures and cultural flows. At the same time, corporations are producers and disseminators, and thus have effects on their surrounding environments, effects that extend from the local to the global. This course examines modern corporations from these three perspectives through theoretical and ethnographic readings, guest speakers from the corporate world, and independent research conducted by the students. Course requirements include student presentations of their research and readings; one or more take-home exams; and a final research paper.

One student stated that Anthropology 346 was a “great course” but that Professor Urban should “improve [the] relevance of readings.” Similarly, another student believed that there was a “great class structure” but that the “readings [were] not 100% relevant.” A third student “enjoyed the great speakers!” With regard to the class discussions, one student mentioned that they “could be more focused…but tangents are always interesting.”  

One student commented on Professor Urban’s enthusiasm, stating that “Professor Urban actually wants to teach his material.” Another student wished that there could have been more class time dedicated to vibrant and engaging discussion led by Professor Urban. 

One student felt that “the project was fascinating…[and that] Professor Urban did a great job helping us think things through.” Another student commented on the “mix of Wharton and College students” and how “such different approaches to the topic [yielded] great class discussions.” A third student suggested that “research facilitators should be better informed as to what the projects will entail.” Another student believed that “the course would be more enjoyable with lighter readings.”
